Aiming to address the issues of ozone pollution and the more difficult disposal of employed lithium batteries, a novel nickel-manganese layered double hydroxide catalyst (Ni-MLB-LDH) was prepared by utilizing the spent manganate lithium battery (MLB) leaching solution as a raw material and applied to the treatment of ozone pollution. Ni-MLB-LDH has an ultra-high specific surface area (130.3 m2/g), smaller grain size and more defect sites than pure NiMn-LDH. Stability testing at RH= 60 % consistently maintained a high decomposition efficiency of over 99 %. XPS and EPR confirmed that Ni-MLB-LDH exhibited more surface oxygen vacancies, which plays a vital role in ozone decomposition. Additionally, incorporating an appropriate proportion of copper into NiMn-LDH can significantly enhance its catalytic activity, whereas doping with aluminium would decrease its catalytic activity. This method provides an emerging route for the resource utilization of spent MLBs and the synthesis of NiMn-LDH. Graphical Abstract Keywords Spent manganate lithium battery NiMn-LDH Ozone decomposition Catalyze Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Unlike upper atmospheric ozone, ground-level ozone is generated by the reaction of nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in the air under sunlight, and is an important component of photochemical smog [1–3]. It is a serious hazard to both the ecosystem and human health [4,5]. The latest World Health Organization Global Air Quality Guidelines indicate that human exposure to ozone should be limited to a concentration of no more than 100 μg/m3 per 8 hours [6]. Long-term exposure to low levels of ozone can cause respiratory illnesses such as asthma, cardiovascular disease, and pneumonia [7–9]. Therefore, it is essential to reduce the concentration of ozone in the human environment. Catalytic decomposition has attracted much attention for its advantages of economy, high efficiency, greenness, energy saving and safety. The key to catalytic decomposition lies in the selection of catalysts, and the widely recognized catalysts are noble metal catalysts (Ag [10]) and transition metal catalysts (Mn [11], Ni [12], Fe [13], Co [14]). Among them, layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have received extensive attention due to their unique ozone decomposition mechanism [15–17]. The key to ozone degradation by conventional ozone catalysts is oxygen vacancies, and they generally have the disadvantages of insufficient active sites, competition for adsorption of water molecules to the active sites, and difficulty in desorption of intermediate oxygen species [8,18]. While LDHs bypasses this reaction mechanism and solves the problem of oxygen vacancy deactivation from the follow up, utilizing its abundant interlayer hydroxyls as active sites and water molecules as reaction intermediates to participate in the reaction cycle, thus solving the problem of catalyst deactivation [15]. Wang et al. [19] investigated the effect of LDHs with different metals on ozone degradation and found that Ni2+ when doped as a divalent metal of LDHs, has an excellent catalytic performance and stability, in which NiMn-LDH showed excellent ozone degradation performance, but its stability performance for ozone degradation and humidity resistance still needs to be improved. Metal doping is the mainstream method to modify the catalysts, and other metal ions are added during the synthesis of the samples to optimize their structures and properties. The diversity of elements in the leach solution of lithium-ion battery shows the advantage at this moment. In addition, driven by the Chinese "dual-carbon" strategy, the production and consumption of lithium batteries have shown explosive growth [20,21]. At the same time, the effective treatment of a large number of used lithium batteries has become a major problem [22,23]. Heavy metals and toxic electrolytes contained in used lithium batteries may harm the ecological environment and human health, and traditional waste treatment methods such as landfills and incineration have severe negative impacts and do not conform to the concept of sustainable development [23,24]. Currently, pyrometallurgy and hydrometallurgy are the main recycling processes for lithium batteries [20]. However, both methods are accompanied by high energy consumption and many secondary pollution problems. In recent years, converting waste lithium batteries into functional materials has been promising [25,26]. Cheng et al. [27] prepared a Co-doped TiO2 catalyst using waste LIB as a Co source, and they found that the catalyst prepared by this method is more cost-efficient than pure Co source and has more excellent performance. Preparing environmentally functional materials using waste LIB effectively alleviates the environmental problems caused by waste LIB, reduces energy consumption and pollution emission, simplifies the complex separation-purification steps, and significantly saves the cost of synthesizing functional materials while maintaining their initial activity [28]. Synthesizing the above two aspects, this paper prepared NiMn-LDH by using spend MLBs leaching solution and Mn(NO3)2 solution as manganese precursor, respectively, and compared the catalytic activities of the two in the ozone decomposition process. It aims to provide a new application route for the resourceization of spent lithium batteries and a new idea for the synthesis of NiMn- LDHs for ozone-catalyzed oxidation. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Extraction of manganate lithium battery cathode material leachate The used MLBs cells were fully immersed in 5 % (v%) NaCl solution to fully discharge them. The battery casing was sawn, and the cells were disassembled and sorted into positive materials and residual parts (negative materials, iron casing, diaphragm, and electrolyte). The positive electrode material was dried naturally in a fume hood and subsequently cut into small square pieces and roasted in a muffle furnace at 600°C to remove the PVDF. The roasted positive electrode pieces were pulverized by a pulverizer and sieved to finally obtain the positive electrode active powder. The above anode active powder was placed in 4 mol/L H2SO4 and 5 % (v%) H2O2 at a solid-liquid ratio of 20:1 (g/L), a leaching temperature of 70°C and a leaching time of 2 h. After the leaching was completed, the mixture was filtered through a filter membrane to obtain a clarified leach solution. The results of inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) of the leachate are shown in Table 1. 2.2 Preparation of catalyst The catalyst was prepared using a hydrothermal method. Take the leaching solution with 5 mmol Mn2+, add deionized water to 150 mL therein, then add NaOH to adjust the pH of the solution to 3, then add 15 mmol NiSO4·6 H2O to the mixed solution, stir well, then add 10 mmol 30 % H2O2 solution and 66 mmol urea, and stir vigorously for 30 min, and then pour the obtained solution into an autoclave reactor with a polytetrafluoroethylene liner. After the reaction at 120℃ for 12 h, the precipitate was filtered, washed to neutral with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water, and dried under vacuum at 60℃ for 12 h to obtain the catalyst, which was denoted as Ni-MLB-LDH. Under the same preparation conditions as that of Ni-MLB-LDH, the acid-impregnated solution was substituted with 50 % Mn(NO3)2 solution, and the catalyst obtained was named as NiMn-LDH. The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) results of the above catalysts are shown in Table 1. A series of Cu-doped and Al-doped NiMn-LDHs were prepared by adding different ratios of Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O and Al(NO3)3·9 H2O under the same preparation conditions as that of the NiMn-LDH, and they were named as NiMn-LDH-Cu0.125, NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25, NiMn-LDH-Cu0.5, NiMn-LDH-Al0.075, NiMn-LDH-Al0.15, NiMn-LDH-Al0.3. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations XRD, FT-IR, BET, SEM, TEM and HRTEM were used to analyze the microstructure and chemical properties of the materials. XPS and EPR were used to study the surface atomic states and oxygen vacancies. Full details of the experimental characterization are presented in the Supporting Information. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The ozonolysis activity was tested by placing 150 mg of catalyst of size 40–60 mesh in a continuous flow quartz reactor (Φ=7 mm), which was placed in a water bath at 30°C to ensure a stable reaction temperature. Ozone was generated by an ozone generator (UV-S-CNPRO, TONGLIN, China) and the inlet concentration was controlled by an ozone detector (106-L, 2B Technologies, USA) at 50 ± 2 ppm. The relative humidity was controlled by adjusting the flow rate through the water bulb bottle and measured by a hygrometer (AS847, SMART SENSOR, China) to ensure the stability of the reaction temperature. China) to ensure humidity stabilization. The total flow rate was 1 L/min, WHSV= 400 L·g−1·h −1. The ozone conversion of the catalyst was calculated from equation (Eq. 1): (1) Ozone conversion = C in − C out C in × 100 % Cin is the concentration at the ozone inlet and Cout is the concentration at the ozone outlet. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal structures and surface areas The XRD spectra of the catalysts were tested to investigate their crystal structures, as shown in Fig. 1a, the diffraction peaks at 11.5°, 23.1°, 34.1°, 39°, 46.2°, 60.1° and 61.3° can be attributed to the (003), (006), (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) crystallographic planes of the LDHs, which are typical diffraction peaks of LDHs, and are consistent with the (JCPDS card No. 38–0715) [29]. Compared to NiMn-LDH, Ni-MLB-LDH has lower diffraction peak intensities, suggesting a reduced crystallinity, which in turn suggests that it may have more surface defects, favoring the catalytic decomposition of ozone. In addition, the layer spacing of the LDHs was calculated using Bragg's law (Eq. 2) calculations and the 2θ angle of the (003) crystallographic plane to be approximately 0.78 nm, which is consistent with the reported LDHs of CO3 2- intercalation. (2) 2 dsin θ = n λ The samples were analyzed by Fourier infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), as shown in Fig. 1b, the broad bands at 3427–3503 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups in the LDHs layer, and the peak at 1630 cm−1 is attributed to the hydroxyl deformation mode of water molecules in the interlayer [30]. The results indicate that OH groups exist in the samples and water molecules exist in the interlayers. The characteristic absorption peak at 1370 cm−1 corresponds to the vibrational absorption of CO3 2- in the interlayers [31]. The characteristic absorption peak at 1067 cm−1 in Ni-MLB-LDH corresponds to the vibrational absorption of SO4 2- [32], which may be attributed to the involvement of sulfate in the MLB leaching solution in the reaction, which makes a part of SO4 2- doped into the interlayers of LDH. In addition, the bands observed in the range of 1000–600 cm−1 were interpreted as belonging to the vibrational modes of metal-oxygen (M-O) or metal-hydroxyl (M-OH) groups[19]. The XRD and FT-IR results informed that the catalysts prepared using used MLBs leachate and manganese nitrate preparation were all NiMn-LDHs, where the interlayer anions of Ni-MLB-LDH were CO3 2- and SO4 2-, and the interlayer anion of NiMn-LDH was CO3 2-. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1c. Ni-MLB-LDH shows type IV isotherms with H4 hysteresis loops, and the H4 hysteresis is a composite of the type I and type II adsorption isotherms, which suggests that the sample has a narrow pore space and a mixed microporous and mesoporous structure. structure. Fig. 1d also confirms that the pore size of Ni-MLB-LDH is a microporous structure, which has smaller pore size Ni-MLB-LDH (1.47 nm) < NiMn-LDH (7.45 nm). In addition, the average particle size dimensions of the two catalysts conformed to this trend ( Table 2). As show in Table 2, the specific surface area of Ni-MLB-LDH (130.4 m2/g) was much higher than that of NiMn-LDH (40.1 m2/g). It can be inferred from this that Ni-MLB-LDH may expose more active sites due to the larger specific surface area. Therefore, Ni-MLB-LDH obtained from used MLBs batteries has a larger specific surface area and smaller grain size, which may be related to the more mesoporous structure produced by the doping of transition metals in the battery leachate, which may enable the catalyst to possess higher catalytic performance. 3.2 Crystal morphology and microstructure SEM and TEM images are shown in Fig. 2. Fig. 2(a-d) shows that both Ni-MLB-LDH and NiMn-LDH exhibit irregular flower cluster-like structures. The grain size of Ni-MLB-LDH is mainly concentrated in the range of 100–350 nm and some of the lamellar structure produces agglomeration, which may be due to the decrease in crystallinity caused by the transition metal doping, which further affects the morphology of the LDHs. The grain size of NiMn-LDH is mainly concentrated in the range of 100–600 nm and also more dispersed. Figs. 2e and 2g show the TEM images of Ni-MLB-LDH and NiMn-LDH. It can also be seen from Figs. 2e and 2g that both materials have a lamellar structure and Ni-MLB-LDH has a smaller grain size than NiMn-LDH. Further analyzing the morphology by HRTEM, the lattice spacing in Fig. 2f is 0.204 nm and 0.238 nm, which is consistent with the spacing of the (015) and (018) crystal faces of NiMn-LDH, respectively. The spacing of the exposed crystal faces in Fig. 2h is 0.228 nm, which is consistent with the spacing of the (015) crystal faces of NiMn- LDHs. The above results are in agreement with those of XRD, confirming the crystal structure of these catalysts. The SEM-EDS of Ni-MLB-LDH and NiMn-LDH are shown in Fig. 2(i-l), and it can be seen that Ni, Mn, O, and C are uniformly distributed on the surface of the catalysts, which has a positive promotion. 3.3 Surface chemical components and active species The surface elemental composition and valence distribution of the solid materials were tested using XPS. Fig. S1 shows the full-scan XPS spectra of each sample. The elements Ni, Mn, O and C were present in two samples. Fig. 3a shows the Ni 2p spectra of the catalyst. In NiMn-LDH, the peaks located at 855.4 eV and 873.0 eV can be attributed to Ni2+, the peaks located at 856.6 eV and 874.5 eV can be attributed to Ni3+, and the peaks located at 861.6 eV and 879.6 eV can be attributed to satellite peaks (Sat.). For Ni-MLB-LDH, peaks located at 855.5 eV and 873.1 eV can be assigned to Ni2+, peaks located at 856.9 eV and 874.7 eV can be assigned to Ni3+, and peaks located at 861.6 eV and 879.8 eV can be attributed to satellite peaks (Sat.) [33]. Both Ni2+ and Ni3+, and the ratio of Ni2+/Ni3+ in Ni-MLB-LDH is larger than that of NiMn-LDH (1.35 >1.20) in both samples, indicating that Ni-MLB-LDH has more Ni2+ content. Fig. 3b shows the Mn 2p spectra of the catalysts. For NiMn-LDH, the peaks are 642.5 eV and 653.6 eV, respectively, and the spin-orbit splitting is 11.1 eV, which is consistent with the characteristics of Mn3+. For Ni-MLB-LDH, the peaks are 642.7 eV and 653.8 eV, respectively, and the spin-orbit splitting is 11.1 eV, again conforming to the features of Mn3+ [34]. However, the binding energy of Mn 2p was slightly elevated in Ni-MLB-LDH compared to NiMn-LDH, indicating that the chemical valence of Mn species in Ni-MLB-LDH was slightly higher than that of NiMn-LDH. The average oxidation state (AOS) of Mn was obtained by Mn 3 s spectra (Fig. S2). The AOS of each sample is shown in Table S3. The results show that Ni-MLB-LDH has a higher average oxidation state, consistent with the Mn 2p results [35]. Fig. 3c shows the O 1 s spectra of the catalysts. For NiMn-LDH, it was convolved into four peaks, which were lattice oxygen at 529.5 eV (Olatt), hydroxyl oxygen at 531.1 eV (OOH), oxygen vacancy at 531.9 eV (OV), and chemisorbed oxygen at 533 eV (Oads). Ni-MLB-LDH was also convolved into four peaks, which were lattice oxygen at 529.8 eV (Olatt), hydroxyl oxygen at 531.1 eV (OOH), oxygen vacancies at 531.9 eV (OV), and chemisorbed oxygen at 533.2 eV (Oads) [36,37]. Although oxygen atoms are not present in Ov, they can adsorb hydroxyl or oxygen due to the imprinting effect [38], and thus the XPS properties of these substances can indicate the presence of OV. Therefore, the peaks near 532 eV were categorized as OV [39]. As shown in the table S3, the percentage of OV in NiMn-LDH was 20.6 %, whereas the percentage of OV in Ni-MLB-LDH was as high as 36.7 %, which implies that the modification of the transition metal in the MLB leach solution significantly increased the concentration of OV on the surface of the samples. In both samples, the OOH species accounted for the highest percentage, suggesting that metal hydroxides occupy the dominant phase of the catalysts. Fig. S3 shows the XPS spectra of other elements in the spent MLBs. Two distinct peaks appeared at 940 eV to 950 eV in the Cu 2p XPS, which proved the presence of Cu element, mainly in the form of Cu2+, in Ni-MLB-LDH [40]. Meanwhile, a peak appeared at 68.2 eV and 72.8 eV in the Al 2p XPS, indicating the presence of Al3+ in Ni-MLB-LDH [41]. However, no prominent peak existed in the XPS spectrum of Li 1 s, which proved that the catalyst contained almost no Li element, consistent with the results of ICP-AES. The oxygen vacancy concentration in the samples was further characterized by EPR. As shown in Fig. 3d, Ni-MLB-LDH produced a relatively strong signal at g= 2.003, while a relatively weak signal could be observed for NiMn-LDH. The signal located around g= 2.003 is attributed to oxygen vacancies [42]. The higher the intensity of the peak, the higher the concentration of oxygen vacancies. This is consistent with the results for O 1 s in XPS. Therefore, the preparation of catalysts using MLB leach solution can promote the formation of defects in NiMn-LDH. 3.4 Ozone decomposition performance 3.4.1 Catalytic performance comparison of Ni-MLB-LDH and NiMn-LDH The ozone degradation performance of both samples was evaluated under ambient (Cin=50 ppm, T = 30°C, WHSV=400 L·g−1·h−1, RH=0 %). As shown in Fig. 4a, Ni-MLB-LDH exhibited excellent ozone catalytic performance at 4 h, consistently maintaining 100 % degradation efficiency, while the degradation efficiency of NiMn-LDH showed a continuous decreasing trend to 95.9 % after 4 h. The degradation efficiency of Ni-MLB-LDH was also found to be very high. The humidity resistance of the two catalysts was further investigated. The performance of the two catalysts was evaluated at RH= 60 %. As shown in Fig. 4b, Ni-MLB-LDH still showed excellent ozone degradation performance, with a conversion of 99.5 % after 4 h. The ozone removal rate of NiMn-LDH was still lower than that of Ni-MLB-LDH, with a conversion of 67.3 % after 4 h of reaction. Fig. 4c shows that Ni-MLB-LDH has superior ozone conversion than Ni-Mn-LDH at different humidity levels (0 %, 30 %, 60 %, and 90 %). The above results indicate that the performance of catalysts prepared from MLB leaching solution is higher than that of catalysts prepared from pure substances, which may be attributed to its larger specific surface area and higher oxygen vacancy concentration. The comparison of the ozone degradation performance of the two samples under a change in relative humidity from 60 % to 90 % was continued (Fig. 4d, e). As we can see, the catalytic activity of the samples decreases rapidly once switching from 60 % RH to 90 % RH. Then, by switching from 90 % RH condition to 60 % RH, the ozone removal rate of the sample will recover rapidly. The results indicate that the concentration of water molecules is a key factor in determining the ozone degradation performance of the catalyst. However, the degradation efficiency of Ni-MLB-LDH was consistently higher than that of NiMn-LDH. In summary, Ni-MLB-LDH prepared using MLB leaching solution has stronger water resistance. In addition, Ni-MLB-LDH also showed excellent catalytic performance and stability after long-term reaction at RH= 60 % for 24 h (Fig. 4f), consistently maintaining a high decomposition efficiency of about 99 % at an WHSV of 400 L·g−1·h−1; and a stable ozone degradation performance (70.8 %) even at a high WHSV of 800 L·g−1·h−1. 3.4.2 Performance and structure discussion The catalytic activity of NiMn-LDH is related to various factors such as crystal structure, specific surface area, morphology, oxygen vacancies, etc. Ni-MLB-LDH is a LDHs with transition metal doping prepared from the MLB leaching solution. The doping of the transition metal elements, such as Cu, Al, etc., indirectly leads to the formation of defects, which promotes the transitions of the susceptible electrons, and thus results in an acceleration of the redox reaction [43]. In addition, these defects also favor the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which is important for improving the ozone decomposition activity of the catalyst. The higher concentration of oxygen vacancies facilitates the mitigation of the competing adsorption of water molecules on the catalyst surface. Notably, the specific surface area of Ni-MLB-LDH is 3.25 times higher than that of NiMn-LDH, and the increase in specific surface area also increases the contact area of the catalyst with ozone, exposing more active sites. In summary, among NiMn-LDH and Ni-MLB-LDH, Ni-MLB-LDH has the largest specific surface area and pore volume, stable crystalline structure, abundant defect sites and oxygen vacancy concentration, and it is reasonable that it has the best catalytic performance under the combined effect of many factors. 3.5 Effect of Cu and Al doped for the catalytic performance of NiMn-LDH The results of ICP-AES indicate that Cu and Al are the two main doping elements in NiMn-LDH. Therefore, we doped NiMn-LDH with different ratios of Cu and Al, respectively, and investigated their effects on the catalytic performance. As can be seen from Fig. 5a, all three Al-doped NiMn-LDHs have lower ozone decomposition performance than the undoped NiMn-LDH, indicating that Al2+ doping can reduce the ozone decomposition activity of NiMn-LDH. From Fig. 5b, it can be seen that all three Cu-doped NiMn-LDHs have higher ozone decomposition performance than undoped Cu-doped NiMn-LDH, indicating that Cu2+ doping promotes the ozone decomposition activity of NiMn-LDH. To further explore the effects of Al and Cu elemental doping on NiMn-LDHs, we selected NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 and NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 for a series of characterizations. Fig. 5c shows the nitrogen adsorption-desorption curves of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 and NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25. Both show type II isotherms with H3 hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of both macroporous and mesoporous structures. As shown in Table 2, the specific surface area of NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 (85.7 m2/g) was higher than that of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 (76.6 m2/g), which might be the reason for the higher ozonolysis performance of NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25. Figs. 5d and 5e show the SEM images of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 and NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25, respectively. Their morphologies are similar to that of NiMn-LDH, and both are flower cluster-like structures. Among them, the average grain size of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 increased to 378.9 nm, whereas the average grain size of NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 was close to that of Ni-MLB-LDH, which was 259.9 nm. The smaller grain size was favorable for the catalytic reaction, which was in line with that of the NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 and the NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25. The EPR profiles of the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 5f. NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 has a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies than NiMn-LDH, and the opposite is true for NiMn-LDH- Al0.15. In general, the concentration of oxygen vacancies plays a positive role in ozone decomposition. This is also consistent with the performance of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 and NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25. We further analyzed the XPS of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 and NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 before and after the reaction. Fig. 5g shows the XPS patterns of Mn 2p. The spin-orbital of NiMn-LDH-Al0.15 splits from 11.1 eV to 11.4 eV, and the spin-orbital of NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 splits from 11.1 eV to 11.3 eV after the reaction. This implies the elevation of their Mn elemental valence state, which may result from ozone oxidization. NiMn-LDH -Cu0.25 shows less change, which indicates that it is more structurally stable. Fig. 5h shows the Ni 2p spectrum. Like the results of Mn 2p, the Ni2+ content decreased, and the Ni3+ content increased after the reaction. Moreover, the NiMn-LDH-Cu0.25 is changed to a lesser extent, indicating that the Cu element doped NiMn-LDH has a more stable structure. Fig. 5i shows the O 1 s spectra before and after the catalyst reaction. The results show that both are catalysts dominated by hydroxide species. Moreover, the Cu element doped NiMn-LDH has a higher OV concentration and superior catalytic performance. The results of O 1 s after the reaction showed a slight increase in Oads, which might be caused by the adsorption of water molecules by the catalyst under a high-humidity environment. A slight decrease in the OV content might be caused by intermediate oxygen species' occupation of some surface oxygen vacancies. In addition, there was a significant decrease in OOH content and a large increase in Olatt content, which could be attributed to the gradual transition of the catalyst to the metal oxide state due to the instability of the hydroxyl structure under the ozone environment. Comparing the two, the Cu element-doped catalyst has higher stability, higher oxygen vacancy concentration, and stronger water molecule desorption ability under the ozone environment, which gives it a more excellent ozonolysis performance. In summary, the Cu ion-doped NiMn-LDH has a larger specific surface area, smaller grain size, higher surface oxygen vacancy concentration, and more stable structure, which in turn possesses a more excellent ozonolysis activity. In contrast, the Al ion-doped catalyst has an increase in the grain size and a decrease in the surface oxygen vacancy concentration, which leads to a decrease in the catalytic activity, which is reasonable. 3.6 Mechanistic analysis Based on previous studies, the H-transfer redox mechanism of ozone degradation by LDHs was obtained by first-principle calculations, and the hydroxyl group was considered as the main active site [15]. The reaction process is as follows: firstly, an O3 molecule combines with two hydroxyl groups and reacts to form oxygen and water molecules; then, two water molecules adsorbed on four M-O sites react to form an oxygen molecule and reduce to four hydroxyl groups, and the regeneration of the catalyst is realized in this step. The water molecules were involved in the ozone decomposition process as reaction intermediates, which effectively avoided the deactivation due to the competitive adsorption of water molecules. O3 + 2M-OH → O2 + H2O + 2M-O H2O + 2M-O → 2M-OH + 1/2O2 The reaction mechanism was further analyzed by XPS mapping before and after the reaction of Ni-MLB-LDH. Fig. 6a shows the Mn 2p spectra of fresh and used Ni-MLB-LDH. For Ni-MLB-LDH-U, the spin orbital splits from 11.1 eV to 11.4 eV, which implies an increase in the chemical valence state of elemental Mn, which may be caused by oxidation by ozone [44]. Fig. 6b shows the Ni 2p spectra of fresh and used Ni-MLB-LDH. There was no significant difference in the binding energy of the Ni 2p3/2 orbitals of the catalysts before and after the reaction, and the Ni2+/Ni3+ of Ni-MLB-LDH was increased from 1.35 to 1.38, and the increase in the content of Ni2+ might be due to the electron transfer from the elevated valence state of Mn ions. Fig. 6c shows the O 1 s spectra of fresh and used Ni-MLB-LDH. Oads content increased from 8.6 % to 10.0 %, which might be caused by the accumulation of water molecules on the catalyst surface; the decrease of OOH content and the increase of Olatt content might be due to the conversion of some hydroxyl groups into lattice oxygen, which might be caused by the instability of hydroxyl structure of Ni-MLB-LDH under the condition of high ozone concentration leading to the gradual transition to the metal-oxide state [16]; there was no significant change in the OV content, which indicated that its surface OV vacancies were not occupied by water molecules and peroxides, which had a strong desorption ability for it [45]. Therefore, the mechanism of ozone decomposition by the synergistic action of hydroxyl groups and oxygen vacancies in Ni-MLB-LDH is shown in Fig. 6d. 3.7 Economic analysis We estimated the prices of manganese sources required to produce 1 kg Ni-MLB-LDH and 1 kg Mn-MLB-LDH. The market price of 50 % manganese nitrate solution (CAS No. 10377–66–9) is about 65.28 ¥/kg. The 50 % Mn(NO3)2 solution required for producing 1 kg Ni-MLB-LDH is about 2076.4 g, a total of 135.54 ¥. For the Mn2+ needed to produce 1 kg Ni-MLB-LDH, the cost is calculated according to the consumption of sulfuric acid, H2O2, electricity, and other chemical reagents, and the price needed to produce the leaching solution is 0.386 ¥/L. The amount of the leaching solution needed to produce 1 kg of Mn-MLB-LDH is 11.64 L, and in addition to that, 3.56 kg of NaOH (3.7 ¥/kg) is needed as a pH adjuster, totaling 17.71 ¥. The use of a Mn2+ source recovered from used lithium-ion batteries to produce Mn-MLB-LDH can result in significant cost savings compared to NiMn-LDH, and, significantly, the ozonolysis performance of the resultant Mn-MLB-LDH is not weakened, and is even better than that of NiMn-LDH. 4 Conclusion NiMn-LDHs with transition metal doping were prepared using MLB leaching solution as raw material. The prepared Ni-MLB-LDH showed higher ozone decomposition performance than Ni-MLB-LDH under all humidity conditions, demonstrating stronger water resistance and stability. Under WHSV= 400,000 mL·g−1·h−1 and RH= 60 %, the decomposition efficiency of Ni-MLB-LDH for 50 ppm ozone reached 98.8 % after 24 h of operation. After a series of characterization results, it was concluded that the Cu element in the leach solution played an important role, and the doping of the Cu element enabled the catalyst to have a smaller grain size, abundant oxygen vacancy concentration, larger specific surface area and stable structure. In addition, the catalysts prepared from MLB leaching solution have higher environmental and economic values, which provides a meaningful reference for recycling spent MLB to prepare environmentally functional materials. coredata.dc:description: Aiming to address the issues of ozone pollution and the more difficult disposal of employed lithium batteries, a novel nickel-manganese layered double hydroxide catalyst (Ni-MLB-LDH) was prepared by utilizing the spent manganate lithium battery (MLB) leaching solution as a raw material and applied to the treatment of ozone pollution. Ni-MLB-LDH has an ultra-high specific surface area (130.3 m2/g), smaller grain size and more defect sites than pure NiMn-LDH. Stability testing at RH= 60 % consistently maintained a high decomposition efficiency of over 99 %. XPS and EPR confirmed that Ni-MLB-LDH exhibited more surface oxygen vacancies, which plays a vital role in ozone decomposition. Additionally, incorporating an appropriate proportion of copper into NiMn-LDH can significantly enhance its catalytic activity, whereas doping with aluminium would decrease its catalytic activity. This method provides an emerging route for the resource utilization of spent MLBs and the synthesis of NiMn-LDH.
